action.action-desc: Mr. Austin Scott of Georgia introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend titles 5 and 28, United States Code, to facilitate recovering the costs of litigation and agency adjudications for prevailing parties in an action against the United States, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Halting Government Overreach Act of 2015.

section.header: Changing limitations on recovery of fees and expenses by the prevailing party in an action against the United States

subparagraph.text: Section 2412(d) of title 28, United States Code, is amended—

clause.text: in paragraph (1)(A), by striking , unless the court finds that the position of the United States was substantially justified or that special circumstances make an award unjust;

in paragraph (1)(B), by striking The party shall also allege that the position of the United States was not substantially justified. Whether or not the position of the United States was substantially justified shall be determined on the basis of the record (including the record with respect to the action or failure to act by the agency upon which the civil action is based) which is made in the civil action for which fees and other expenses are sought.; and

in paragraph (3), by striking , unless the court finds that during such adversary adjudication the position of the United States was substantially justified, or that special circumstances make an award unjust.

subparagraph.text: Section 2412(d)(2) of title 28, United States Code, is amended by striking subparagraph (D).

paragraph.text: Section 2412(d)(1)(A) of title 28, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following: Such award may only be made if the prevailing party has a direct and personal interest in the action because of an injury that gave rise to the action..

paragraph.header: Excluding net worth from the definition of party
paragraph.text: Section 2412(d)(2)(B) of title 28, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: by striking whose net worth did not exceed $2,000,000 at the time the civil action was filed;
by striking , the net worth of which did not exceed $7,000,000 at the time the civil action was filed, and; and
by striking ; except and all that follows through defined in section 601 of title 5.
Section 504 of title 5, United States Code, is amended—

clause.text: in subsection (a)(1), by striking , unless the adjudicative officer of the agency finds that the position of the agency was substantially justified or that special circumstances make an award unjust. Whether or not the position of the agency was substantially justified shall be determined on the basis of the administrative record, as a whole, which is made in the adversary adjudication for which fees and other expenses are sought; and
in subsection (a)(2), by striking The party shall also allege that the position of the agency was not substantially justified..

subparagraph.text: Section 504(b)(1) of title 5, United States Code, is amended—

clause.text: in subparagraph (D), by adding and at the end; and

paragraph.text: Section 504(a)(1) of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following: Such award may only be made if the prevailing party has a direct and personal interest in the proceeding because of an injury that gave rise to the proceeding..

paragraph.header: Excluding net worth from the definition of party
paragraph.text: Section 504(b)(1)(B) of title 5, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: by striking whose net worth did not exceed $2,000,000 at the time the adversary adjudication was initiated;
by striking , the net worth of which did not exceed $7,000,000 at the time the adversary adjudication was initiated, and ; and
by striking ; except and all that follows through defined in section 601.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to actions initiated after the date of the enactment of this Act.
